abstract: Research finds gun homicide rate in Missouri rose 16 percent in six years after it repealed requirement for background checks and purchase permits for firearms in 2007, while national rate fell 11 percent; data offers insight into what can happen when a state relaxes gun control rules, though experts warn that there may not be direct correlation between law change and homicide rate.
lead_paragraph: The gun homicide rate has risen since the state repealed gun control measures in 2007, but experts caution that it does not mean the law change is the reason.

headline.main: In Missouri, Fewer Gun Restrictions and More Gun Killings
headline.print_headline: Gun Killings Rise as Controls Ease Across Missouri

snippet: The gun homicide rate has risen since the state repealed gun control measures in 2007, but experts caution that it does not mean the law change is the reason.
